Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: The Mother Superior has asked the nun to lead a series of daily reflections for the entire community during an upcoming retreat.
Story: Every Sunday evening, I call my parents. It’s a ritual that grounds me, a thread connecting my life as their daughter to the quiet halls of the convent. My mother always asks about my health, my father tells me about the garden, and I listen, feeling their love across the miles. This week, though, the Mother Superior has asked me to lead daily reflections for our upcoming retreat. It’s an honor, but it means hours of preparation—reading, meditating, and writing—leaving little time for anything else. As Sunday approaches, I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in. My parents will wait for my call, expecting the comfort of my voice, while my sisters here look to me for spiritual guidance. I sit in my small room, torn between the gentle pull of family and the sacred duty I’ve chosen. My heart aches with the knowledge that I cannot give myself fully to both, and I wonder which part of me must wait.
